articles.headline: On Harris’s Price-Gouging Ban, Allies and Foes May Have the Wrong Idea
articles.snippet: The plan does not appear to amount to government price controls. It also might not bring down grocery bills anytime soon.
articles.abstract: The plan does not appear to amount to government price controls. It also might not bring down grocery bills anytime soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris threw her support behind a federal ban on price-gouging in the food and grocery industries last week. It was the first official economic policy proposal of her presidential campaign, and it was pitched as a direct response to the high price of putting food on the table in America today.

articles.headline: Democrats Use the Convention to Try to Define Trump as a Self-Interested Fraud
articles.snippet: Speeches and videos seek to shrink Donald Trump in order to rise above him, as Kamala Harris and her allies work to minimize him and disengage from him.
articles.abstract: Speeches and videos seek to shrink Donald Trump in order to rise above him, as Kamala Harris and her allies work to minimize him and disengage from him.
articles.lead_paragraph: How to attack former President Donald Trump?
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: U.S. Investigating Americans Who Worked With Russian State Television
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. raided the homes of two prominent commentators on Russian state television channels as part of an effort to blunt attempts to influence November’s election.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. raided the homes of two prominent commentators on Russian state television channels as part of an effort to blunt attempts to influence November’s election.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice has begun a broad criminal investigation into Americans who have worked with Russia’s state television networks, signaling an aggressive effort to combat the Kremlin’s influence operations leading up to the presidential election in November, according to American officials briefed on the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: A Combat Medic’s Quest to Change Tributes to Fallen Soldiers
articles.snippet: Iryna Tsybukh, who was killed on the front line in Ukraine, wanted to humanize the way Kyiv commemorated the war dead. She also left notes for her own funeral.
articles.abstract: Iryna Tsybukh, who was killed on the front line in Ukraine, wanted to humanize the way Kyiv commemorated the war dead. She also left notes for her own funeral.
articles.lead_paragraph: Her funeral would be “awesome,” the young Ukrainian combat medic said, if it went as she had planned.

articles.headline: Canadian Government Orders Arbitration and End to Rail Freight Shutdown
articles.snippet: The shutdown had threatened to disrupt trade with the United States and other countries, as well as cause serious economic consequences in Canada.
articles.abstract: The shutdown had threatened to disrupt trade with the United States and other countries, as well as cause serious economic consequences in Canada.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than 17 hours after almost all rail freight traffic in Canada came to a standstill Thursday following a lockout by the country’s two main rail companies of 10,000 employees, the federal government told a labor board to end the shutdown and ordered arbitration.

articles.headline: Trump May Claim Credit for Stock Surges, but the Reality Is Far More Complicated
articles.snippet: On Wall Street, claims that a president is responsible for the fate of the stock market are largely dismissed as bluster.
articles.abstract: On Wall Street, claims that a president is responsible for the fate of the stock market are largely dismissed as bluster.
articles.lead_paragraph: As president, Donald J. Trump continually took credit for a rising stock market, citing it as evidence that his economic policies were enriching Americans.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Powell Faces Economic Crossroads as He Prepares to Speak at Jackson Hole
articles.snippet: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, will deliver remarks as inflation cools and growth holds up — but as labor market weakening threatens to interrupt the soft landing.
articles.abstract: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, will deliver remarks as inflation cools and growth holds up — but as labor market weakening threatens to interrupt the soft landing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Jerome H. Powell took the podium at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City’s annual conference at Jackson Hole in Wyoming and warned America that lowering inflation would require some pain.

articles.headline: Lynch Yacht Sinking Off Sicily Proves as Baffling as It Is Tragic
articles.snippet: As bodies were recovered, the authorities and experts wondered how a $40 million, stable and secure vessel could have sunk so quickly.
articles.abstract: As bodies were recovered, the authorities and experts wondered how a $40 million, stable and secure vessel could have sunk so quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months after being cleared in a bruising legal battle over fraud charges, the British tech mogul Mike Lynch celebrated his freedom with a cruise. He invited his family, friends and part of his legal team on board his luxury sailing yacht, a majestic 180-foot vessel named Bayesian after the mathematical theorem around which he had built his empire.
articles.byline: By Emma Bubola and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Farm Workers Union Battles California Grower Owned by Democratic Donors
articles.snippet: Wonderful Nurseries, owned by Stewart and Lynda Resnick, has sued the state to overturn a labor organizing law championed by the United Farm Workers.
articles.abstract: Wonderful Nurseries, owned by Stewart and Lynda Resnick, has sued the state to overturn a labor organizing law championed by the United Farm Workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The allegations ricocheted through the agricultural fields and into a Central Valley courthouse, where one of California’s most powerful companies and an iconic union were trading charges of deception and coercion in a fight over worker representation.

articles.headline: What Drives Kamala Harris: The Art of the Possible
articles.snippet: As she prepares to formally accept the Democratic nomination on Thursday night, what the vice president may be offering the nation is a future defined by the fine print.
articles.abstract: As she prepares to formally accept the Democratic nomination on Thursday night, what the vice president may be offering the nation is a future defined by the fine print.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2005, one year into her job as San Francisco district attorney, Kamala Harris was showing a new hire around the office.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Erica L. Green and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
